title: 109_hr5699
content: The "Patriot Corporations of America Act of 2006" provides a federal contracting preference for Patriot corporations in the procurement of goods or services. These corporations, defined in the Internal Revenue Code, receive a tax reduction as well. The "Patriot Corporations of America Act of 2006" offers a tax reduction of 5 percent for Patriot corporations certified by the Secretary as meeting specific requirements. The "Patriot Corporations of America Act of 2006" offers a tax reduction of 5 percent for corporations that meet specific requirements, including producing at least 90 percent of goods and services in the US, limiting management compensation, and conducting a significant portion of research and development. The "Patriot Corporations of America Act of 2006" offers tax incentives for corporations meeting specific criteria, including conducting research and development in the US, contributing to a pension fund, providing health insurance, and maintaining neutrality in employee organizing drives. The "Patriot Corporations of America Act of 2006" offers tax incentives for corporations meeting specific criteria, including compliance with federal regulations related to environment, workplace safety, labor relations, and consumer protections as determined by the Secretary. A certification process will be established to annually certify corporations as Patriot corporations. The "Patriot Corporations of America Act of 2006" establishes a certification process to annually certify corporations as Patriot corporations based on specific criteria. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. The Secretary may also certify a corporation as a Patriot corporation for the last taxable year before December 31, 2007, if it meets certain requirements. SEC. 4. Tax avoidance foreign corporations subject to United States income tax. The amendment to section 7701(a) of the Internal Revenue Code defines "domestic" for corporations and partnerships created or organized in the United States or under its laws, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. Foreign corporations engaging in tax avoidance may be treated as domestic if certain conditions are met. The amendment made by this section applies to foreign corporations created to avoid being treated as domestic corporations under the Internal Revenue Code, effective for taxable years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. REDUCTION IN BENEFIT OF RATE REDUCTION FOR FAMILIES WITH INCOMES OVER $1,000,000. Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection that increases taxes for taxpayers with adjusted gross incomes over $1,000,000. The tax imposed will be raised by a percentage of the income exceeding the threshold amount, which is $1,000,000 for joint returns and $500,000 for other returns. The term 'applicable percentage' in the new subsection of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is determined by the Secretary to increase Treasury revenues by offsetting revenue decreases from section 11(e) with increases from section 7701(a)(4)(B) for each taxable year. This subsection does not apply to estates or trusts. The amendment made by this section, effective after December 31, 2006, is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. It does not change tax rates under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
